subject: Accounting
description: SURVEY OF ACCOUNTING  Lecture  Survey of financial and managerial accounting concepts for the non-business major. Students learn about financial statements for merchandising, manufacturing, and service companies. Topics include: accounting cycle, budgeting, standard costing, contribution margins, cost-volume-profit analysis, and decision making.  N 4 N Student Option  Students within accounting and/or business degree programs who have received credit for ACCT 207  are not eligible to take this course without permission.  Fall, Winter, Spring, Summer

subject: Accounting
description: ACCOUNTING EXPERIENCE  Lecture  How do you know whether the job you seek is a good match when you don’t completely understand what the job entails? It may be three years before you have the opportunity to take a tax class, but you may be selected to interview with a firm’s tax practice. Do you want a big firm or a small firm? Does the position require technology skills you currently possess or plan on acquiring? At the end of this class, you should be equipped to make well-informed choices during that first round of interviews, which will lead to initial internship and subsequent job offers that fit your goals, your preferences, and your skills.  N 1 N Pass/Not Pass  Fall   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation  GE2B: Communicate Orally

subject: Accounting

subject: Accounting

description: ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS  Lecture  Accounting information and its place within an organization’s overall management information system. subject: Accounting
description: INFORMTN SECURITY & RISK MGMT  Lecture  This course introduces the fundamental concepts of information and cybersecurity. It covers how to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data and information systems that modern organizations depend upon. The domains examined include network security, risk management, governance, physical security, cryptography, business continuity, and legal issues. Special consideration is given to studying major information security incidents and cybersecurity trends. You will learn about the threats and vulnerabilities facing computer systems and tools and techniques used to secure them.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with MISY 305  . MISY 160  .

subject: Accounting

description: ORGANIC AND SUST FARMING  Lecture  Introduction to sustainable food systems for students with little or no background in agricultural sciences. The history, common practices, regulations, economics, nutritional, environmental and sustainability issues surrounding the organic food industry are discussed within the broad context of sustainable food systems. Students will actively participate in growing crops organically and conventionally on the Newark Farm to develop a fuller understanding of challenges and opportunities of organic farming. Learn about the role of the professional military leader in a democratic society; societal attitudes toward the armed forces; the requisites for maintaining adequate national defense structure; the impact of technological and international developments on strategic preparedness and the overall policy-making process; and military law. In addition, you will study topics that will prepare you for your first active-duty assignment as an officer in the Air Force. subject: Africana Studies
description: WAGES OF WHITENESS  Discussion  If we consider Du Bois’ original assertion that the problem of the 20th century was the problem of the color-line, it prompts us to investigate whether the color-line has created a crisis for the human future, and particularly if that crisis centers around Whiteness and the falsified essence of a White racial identity. As we embark on this journey of inquiry, we will strive to gain insights into the intricate nature of Whiteness, in opposition to blackness, and its lasting impacts.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with HIST 208  .  History and Cultural Change GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change Multicultural Fall and Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally  GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Africana Studies
description: ANCIENT AFRICAN CIVILIZATION  Lecture  This course examines not only ancient history, literature and culture deemed as involving continental African, African diasporic peoples, thus construed as ancient African heritage but also aspects of antiquity and futurity and in particular notions about interpretations connecting African antiquity to African diasporic peoples and African contributions to world civilization. The course reviews ideas about African origins of civilization up to ancient Egypt’s decline at the time of Cleopatra and thus covers the Greco-Roman Egyptian period as well.   The course surveys various perceptions and uses of ancient Egypt, i.e., understood as ancient Egyptian studies from an Africana Studies framework. The course also focuses on Black historiography observed as connecting the Black past to Black diasporic communities’ writ large.Repeatable for Credit:NAllowed Units:3Multiple Term Enrollment:NGrading Basis:Student Option  History and Cultural Change GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change Multicultural Fall, Winter and Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally GE2C: Communication Through Creative Expression GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures  GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Africana Studies
description: INTERSECTIONAL FEMINISM  Lecture  Unpacking the role that white feminism has played in dictating the universal, essential woman, this course interrogates the intersectional frameworks and knowledges produced by women of color that embrace and complicate established feminist frameworks. This course addresses  the inter and intra relationship of women of color with feminism, locally and globally. Using both a theoretical and applied approach, we will analyze how historical and contemporary realities of women of color are influenced by a legacy of structural inequalities. The approach to this course will pay particular attention to sociological aspects of identity as well as cultural representations that are manifestations of systems of oppression. Finally, the course moves beyond intersectionality as “identity politics” and examines the ways in which power is deployed through interlocking systems of oppression including white supremacy, patriarchy, and advanced capitalism.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with WOMS 214  .  History and Cultural Change GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change Multicultural Fall and Spring

subject: Art History
description: PHOTOGRAPHIES 1800-2000  Lecture  Thematic introduction to the history and theory of photography from 1800 to the late twentieth century. Themes include: photography’s invention, global proliferation and cultural and social impact; photographic processes and materials; photographic archiving and metadata; photography’s commercial, anthropological, scientific, industrial, geographic, journalistic, administrative, vernacular, and artistic applications. Considers role of photography in formation and maintenance of national, cultural, and individual identity and personhood. subject: Art History
course_name: Race and Racism: Global History and Representation
description: RACE AND RACISM  Lecture  Racism is a hot-button issue globally. Although thoroughly debunked and are more widely condemned than ever, it nevertheless continues to surface in government policies, popular representations, and brutal acts of violence. What is it that makes racism so intractable? This course works to answer that question by analyzing racism as a problem that’s deeply embedded in Western societies, albeit similarly prevalent in many non-Western countries. We’ll also look at how racism connects with other social categories such as Indigeneity, gender, sexuality, disability, religion and class. And in addition to considering how racism has operated to oppress, exclude and scapegoat, we’ll also be attentive to how marginalized groups have fought back.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with HIST 224  , AFRA 224  , ANTH 224  , ENGL 224  , GEOG 224  , and WOMS 244  . subject: Art History
description: ARTH SOPHOMORE INTERNSHIP  Internship  This course allows UD students, with a minimum of 42 UD credits, to gain basic knowledge and skills from a planned internship experience in art history, architectural history, material culture studies, and art museum practices.  The course is 1-3  credit, requiring a commitment of 15 contract hours per credit per semester.  (For example a 1-credit ARTH264 will require 15 contract hours per semester, where as a 3-credit ARTH264 will require 45 contract hours per semester.)  The internship must be reviewed and approved by the faculty internship Advisor, work-site internship supervisor, and the student before the internship can begin.  N 3 N Student Option  Minimum of 42 UD course credits, Two of ARTH courses (6 credits). subject: Art History
course_name: Studio in the Materials and Techniques of Drawing in the West
description: STUDIO/MAT&TECH DRAWING/WEST  Lecture  Lecture-studio presentation on materials and tools, supports and techniques of wet and dry media drawing in the West from about the year 1400 to the present. Topics include the development and manufacture of paper, pens, brushes, inks, watercolor paint, charcoal, metal points, graphite pencils, natural and fabricated chalks, crayons, pastels, erasers and fixatives. Studio reconstructions of masterworks, lectures and library research.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with ARTC 280  . Requires permission of instructor.  Verify offering with Dept

subject: Art History
description: GLOBAL MODERNISM  Lecture  Surveys the twentieth-century development of modern architecture in various Western and non-Western countries around the world. Emphasis on the encounter of new materials and methods of construction with more traditional techniques, and the symbolic use of architecture to articulate political and cultural identities.  N 3 N Student Option  History and Cultural Change GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change Fall and Spring

subject: Art History
description: MODERN ARCHITECTURE  Lecture  Introduction to architecture of modern periods. Focuses from the eighteenth century to the present. Examines classical texts, rising ideas, and major debates in the field of modern architecture, and explores various connotations of modernity and modernism that have emerged during the past three hundred years around the world. Interdisciplinary approach. Experience with original works of art. subject: Art History
description: PRINTS AND SOCIETY  Lecture  A social history of prints and printmaking techniques, focusing on such major printmakers as Durer, Rembrandt, Piranesi, Goya, Daumier and Picasso. Topics include the role of woodcuts in popular culture, political and satirical prints, posters and advertising, and the connoisseurship of original prints. subject: Art History
description: ART OF THE IBERIAN WORLD  Lecture  The art of Spain and its New World territories from the 15th to the 18th centuries. Emphasis on the negotiation between different artistic and religious traditions in both the Iberian Peninsula (Christian, Muslim, and Jewish) and the Spanish and Portuguese colonies in the Americas (European, African and Native American). Topics vary. Examples: Art and Religion in the Iberian World; Art and Conquest in the Iberian World; Art of the Spanish Renaissance. description: MONET TO PICASSO: ART IN FRANC  Lecture  Art and visual culture in France 1860-1910. Topics include impressionism, symbolism, the avant-garde, women artists, public art, bohemianism, exhibitions, colonialism, primitivism, mass culture, photography, and early cinema. Artists include Manet, Monet, Cezanne, Morisot, Seurat, Van Gogh, Gauguin, Vuillard, Bonnard, Rodin, Matisse, and Picasso. description: ROLE OF THE ARTIST IN SOCIETY  Lecture  Explores changing ideas of the artist from medieval craftsman and Renaissance courtier to Romantic genius and modern revolutionary. Topics include self-portraiture, notions of artistic temperament and genius, women artists and artists’ changing relations with their clients. subject: Art History
description: PHOTOGRAPHY & EVIDENCE  Lecture  Case studies in the history and theory of photography as a form of documentary proof and/or evidence in a wide variety of fields, including journalism, the sciences, the justice system, and foreign and domestic policy. We will consider the technical and cultural bases of photography’s association with certainty and truthfulness and the many challenges, past and present, posed to the medium’s evidentiary authority. subject: Art History
description: PHOTOGRAPHY IN THE US  Lecture  Explores the cultural and scientific histories of photography in the United States beginning with introduction of daguerreotype in 1839. Topics include photography and portraiture, Civil War, western exploration, Pictorialism, and early modernism. Emphasizes study and identification of original photographic materials through introduction to historic photographic processes and materials, such as the ambrotype, tintype, stereograph, and Pictorialist techniques of negative and print manipulation. subject: Art History
course_name: Art of Asia in the Age of Exploration
description: ART OF ASIA AGE OF EXPLORATION  Discussion  Preexisting views of the Age of Exploration typically focus on European explorers and Eurocentric history.  In this course, students learn about the Age of Exploration from the other angle, by examining historical influence of “Asia” on Europe and the world, through the lens of archaeology, art, and architecture.  The course also connects history of art and material culture of East Asia to that of Southeast Asia and South Asia, with extension to part of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. subject: Art History

subject: Art History
description: ANCIENT EGYPT & NUBIA  Discussion  This topic course guides students to examine art and architecture of Africa. Using material culture as evidence.  Students will learn to discuss and argue about people, art, and architecture of Africa, especially in relation to the two most important civilizations of the Nile Valley that turned Africa in the ancient time into the world’s most foundational hub of culture and knowledge. Topics include: “Ancient Egypt & Nubia: Love and War,” “Time and Architecture in Egypt and Nubia,” “The Age of Pharaohs: Empires in Ancient Africa,” among others. subject: Art History
description: CONTEMPORARY BLACK ART  Examines the art and visual culture of the African diaspora since the 1960s. Topics include the Black Arts Movement in the USA and UK, Abstract Expressionism, the Afri-Cobra movement, recycled stereotypes, installation art and performance art.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with AFRA 325  .  Creative Arts and Humanities Multicultural

subject: Art History
description: ISSUES IN BLACK PHOTOGRAPHY  Lecture  A critical race history of blacks as subjects, producers, and theorists of photography. Includes examination of issues, ideas, and creativity with respect to African American and African diasporic photography from the late nineteenth century to the present day. Topics range from portraiture and documentary photography to considerations of race and representation, black consciousness, strategies of resistance and identity formation, class, sex, and gender.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with AFRA 315  .  Creative Arts and Humanities GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities Multicultural

subject: Art History
description: MUSEUM ARTH INTERNSHIP PREP  Practicum  Prepare students for ARTH internships, including an understanding of a range of careers in museums and the work required.  Students meet once a week, one to three contract hour for week depending on the credits designated for the course in that given semester.  Each meeting consists of a combination of discussion, demonstration, and practical lessons.  Sessions include: exhibition organization, checklist development, label and catalog writing; expanding the collection through acquisitions; art, specimen, and object handling; collection care, storage, conservation, and working with museum databases; designing gallery installations and online exhibitions.  Y 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with UAPP 364  . Students must have at least 45 course credits or more. Students must have already completed at least 6 credits of Art History courses. subject: Art History
course_name: Seminar in Orientalism and Postcolonial Art History
description: SEM ORIENTALISM POSTCOLONIAL  Discussion  This is a topic course seminar in which students examine Orientalism and postcolonial discourse in history of art, architecture, archaeology or material culture.  Possible Topics include: “The Orient and Its Representation,” “Japonism and Impressionism,” “Art after Orientalism,” ”Postcolonial Art History and Contemporary Aesthetics,” among others. The seminar allows students to engage with theoretical discourse, while allowing rooms for students to add new perspectives differing from preestablished arguments that have emerged after the publication of Edward Said’s Orientalism. description: SEMINAR AFRICAN-AMERICAN ART  Discussion  In this seminar, which bridges Art History and Africana Studies, students will study and construct a genealogy of African American Art. As a topic seminar, students will engage with a range of subjects foundational to the history of African-American art and examine art in a variety of forms and mediums. Examples of topics include: The Idea of Black Art, Black Art before the 20th century, The Place of Africa in African-American Art, Global-Local Art and African-Diaspora, among others. subject: Art History
course_name: Black Bodies on Display: Race in Museums
description: RACE IN MUSEUMS  Lecture  The complex and performative nature of museums vis-a-vis race, remembrance and reconciliation with a focus on Black American and African Diasporic history and culture. What role[s] do objects, history, and culture perform under such curatorial and museum mandates and visions? How do changing socio-political and cultural landscapes and challenges to representational politics shape museum practices? Considered here are black cultural institutions, their formation and foundation as well as exhibition histories of black visual art and culture.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with AFRA 445  . Open to juniors and seniors only.  History and Cultural Change Multicultural

course_name: Paleo Punk: Evolution and Archaeology of Sex, Drugs, and Rock n Roll
description: PALEO PUNK  Lecture  Explores surprising involvements of ancient humans and Neanderthals in stylish clothes, music, mind-altering substances, and body modification, much like present-day humans. Looks at the paleoanthropological and archaeological evidence for the evolution of music, alcohol, drug use, piercing, and tattoos among early hominins thousands and millions of years ago. subject: Anthropology
description: FORENSIC ANTH  Lecture  Covers basic dental and skeletal anatomy and methods used by biological anthropologists and archaeologists to analyze human remains, especially for the purposes of crime scene investigation and human rights issues. Students will learn to determine age and sex of remains, identify ancestry markers, determine stature and handedness, and identify the presence of trauma and/or pathology. Students interested in medicine, dentistry, public health, and other health professions, as well as criminal justice, law, and archaeology have the opportunity to learn frameworks and skills that are crucial for their future work. subject: Anthropology
description: THE IDEA OF RACE  Lecture  Examines the cultural idea and construction of race in historical and anthropological perspective. Looks at how human differences were interpreted in Europe and America in previous centuries, as well as modern approaches to questions of human variability. Emphasizes how the idea of race has been and remains part of racism and the profound social implications of how the race concept is used in science and medicine, as explored in such case studies as eugenics. subject: Anthropology
description: DECOLONIZING KNOWL: WORLD ANTH  Lecture   Examines the theory and practice of anthropology worldwide to counter the assumption that anthropology is a unified discipline whose most relevant knowledge comes from the West. Addresses how anthropologies in North America and Western Europe exist in complex conversations with anthropologies produced and practiced outside the West, including Latin America, Africa, Asia, and Indigenous North America. Emphasizes the structures of race and gender inequalities that have historically defined anthropology as an academic field, as well as the idea that vibrant conversations between multiple world anthropologies can contribute to robust decolonial (or anti-colonial) agendas for the discipline. Upholds a commitment to undertake anthropology otherwise, seeking to dismantle its historical coloniality by recognizing the diversity of knowledge and numerous ways world anthropologies expand theory, method, and practice. Also analyzes the diverse worlds of practice, engagement, and everyday life linked to different anthropology traditions in different regions. description: DISASTER ANTHROPOLOGY  Lecture  Introduces the growing field of disaster anthropology. subject: Anthropology
description: ANTHROPOLOGY OF HEALTH  Lecture  Conceptualizes health at the crossroads of biology and culture, pathology and person, case and community, experience and world. Emphasizes social, cultural, historical, and structural influences on health alongside clinical medical factors. Covers classic topics such as traditional and alternative medicine, disease versus illness, placebo and nocebo effects, illness narratives, and structural violence. Case studies are drawn from around the world, looking at infectious and chronic disease, diet and nutrition, reproductive health, and mental health, among other topics. Students interested in medicine, public health, nursing, and other health professions have the opportunity to learn frameworks and skills that are crucial for their future work.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with HBNS 106  . subject: Anthropology
description: HIST ANTH THEORY OF ANTH  Lecture  Examines the history of anthropology as a discipline and exciting questions in anthropology today. Considers how theories of society, culture, and diversity have changed over time amid globalization, postcolonialism, feminism, environmentalism, social justice, and other streams of academia and activism. Covers many research methods and forms of practice and engagement in contemporary anthropology.  N 3 N Student Option  Fall and Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information  GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing   GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Anthropology
course_name: Visual Anthropology: Film, Media, and Culture
description: VISUAL ANTHROPOLOGY  Lecture  Anthropology has long been concerned with representions of diverse cultures in film and other visual media. This course examines the history and uses of photography, documentary filmmaking, and social media as modes for representing, investigating, cataloging, and commercializing the social and cultural lives of subjects and places. It questions the process of “othering” that is part of anthropological representation and the visual arts and the historical relationships between documentary aesthetics and colonialism, science, technology, gender, and race. Screenings include films from North America, South America, Asia, Africa, and other regions. This course is of particular interest to students curious about the role of art in society and the relationships between science, knowledge, power, art, and cultural diversity.  N 3 N Student Option  Creative Arts and Humanities GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities Multicultural Fall and Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally  GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications   GE5C: Reason Scientifically

Considers how and why humans differ from other animals. Provides basic understandings of evolutionary theory, fossil interpretation, nonhuman primates, and genetics. subject: Anthropology
description: SOCIAL SCIENCE METHODS IN ANTH  Lecture  Introduces anthropology as a social science and surveys research methods in the field. Covers project design, data collection, qualitative and quantitative analysis, and research ethics. Students develop specialized skills and frameworks that are relevant to many academic disciplines and professional fields. subject: Anthropology
description: WHAT IS HUMAN NATURE?  Lecture  Explores the idea that the human is a unique social, moral, and philosophical being despite the evolutionary contention that the human is a natural animal. Surveys classic human nature arguments regarding sex and gender, race, reproduction, emotions, and other topics, while emphasizing the incredible diversity of human culture and experience. Considers how beliefs about human nature run through religion, politics, and popular assumptions about family, work, crime, and other topics. Emphasizes the crucial linkages between nuanced and complex views of human nature and values of ethics, inclusion, and diversity.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with CGSC 205  . subject: Anthropology
description: FARM TO TABLE  Lecture  How does food get from the farm to your table? Explore traditional agriculture and contemporary food production models like Community Supported Agriculture (CSA), community gardens and the local food movement. Learn about new crops and dietary strategies that can be incorporated into the way people eat today. Examine cultural influences on food production and consumption patterns, and biocultural aspects of nutrition. Students will complete several projects that include interviews, research, food shopping excursions, film critiques and menu planning. Students will volunteer at the Delaware Food Bank and/or Gardens for the Community.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with PLSC 206  , ANFS 206  , and HBNS 206  .

subject: Anthropology

description: PEOP & CULTU: CONT S ASIA  Lecture  Focuses on diverse cultures of contemporary South Asia, emphasizing how history, politics, religion, economy, and globalization shape people’s lives. Case studies include gender, caste systems, labor and work, social conflict, pop culture, social movements, and environmental issues. Covers India, Pakistan, Nepal, and Bangladesh. subject: Anthropology
description: ANTHROPOLOGY OF ISLAM  Lecture  Examines social and cultural dimensions of the Islamic experience, using case studies to survey the Muslim world and understand how Islam is practiced, experienced, and represented in different Muslim societies in the Middle East, sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, Southeast Asia, and the West. Explores interactions between a shared Islamic identity and distinctive local expressions of Muslim faith and life. Investigates how Western scholars have interpreted Islamic societies and cultures. description: INTRO TO MATERIAL CULTURE STDS  Lecture  Introduces the field of material culture studies, the study of all the things people make and the ways people alter the physical world. Considers numerous approaches to understanding material and physical dimensions of life, including architecture, technology, consumer goods, and place. Case studies are drawn from around the world. subject: Anthropology
description: ARCHAEOLOGICAL MYSTERIES  Lecture  Surveys famous archaeological myths and mysteries, such as the lost city of Atlantis, Columbus’s discovery of the New World, Noah’s Ark, the Bermuda Triangle, and UFO crop circles. Examines popular conceptions of Indiana Jones treasure hunting to consider archaeology’s association with gendered and racialized meanings of power, colonialism, territory, violence, and adventure. Addresses unsubstantiated, occult, and speculative claims of archaeological myths and hoaxes, looking at the spread of misinformation and conspiracies in movies, mass media, the internet, and social media. subject: Anthropology
description: TECHNOLOGY AND SOCIETY  Lecture  Introduces anthropological and archaeological approaches to the tools, technologies, and forms of technical knowledge that have shaped diverse societies in the past and today. Case studies range from the technologies that accompanied the rise of agriculture and industry around the world to contemporary cultures of software engineering and robotics. Students acquire critical understandings of how technology can reflect positive or negative futures and how public debates about technology, such as medical or military technology, reflect competing ideas about ethics, progress, and the human. Examples and case studies are drawn from all world regions. subject: Anthropology
description: FOOD, GENDER, AND CULTURE  Lecture  Explores how food preparation and consumption, and attitudes and beliefs about food, reflect diverse gender and power relations across societies. Looks at how globalization, travel, and trade shape understandings of food, gender, health, and identity. Case studies from around the world allow students to think critically about how an essential aspect of humanity, nourishment, is a cultural object and site of meaning and power. subject: Anthropology
course_name: Race and Racism: Global History and Representation
description: RACE AND RACISM  Lecture  Racism is a hot-button issue globally. Although thoroughly debunked and are more widely condemned than ever, it nevertheless continues to surface in government policies, popular representations, and brutal acts of violence. What is it that makes racism so intractable? This course works to answer that question by analyzing racism as a problem that’s deeply embedded in Western societies, albeit similarly prevalent in many non-Western countries. We’ll also look at how racism connects with other social categories such as Indigeneity, gender, sexuality, disability, religion and class. And in addition to considering how racism has operated to oppress, exclude and scapegoat, we’ll also be attentive to how marginalized groups have fought back.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with HIST 224  , AFRA 224  , ARTH 260  , ENGL 224  , GEOG 224  , and WOMS 244  . subject: Anthropology
description: GLOBAL SOUTH STUDIES  Lecture  Examines socioeconomic, political, and cultural processes affecting marginalized populations around the world. Considers the historical mapping and division of the globe into two worlds (first and third, north and south, us and them) despite complicated relationships long connecting places. Analyzes how social and spatial inequalities, ruling classes, forms of power, and boundary mechanisms are reproduced in postcolonial societies and contexts, thinking through intersections of race, class, and gender. Case studies draw from Africa, Asia, Latin America, the Caribbean, and other regions. subject: Anthropology
course_name: USA Today: Contemporary American Culture and Society
description: USA TODAY  Lecture  Examines how people in the United States experience and engage identities and the social forces that shape them. Considers how identities are lived in different areas of the country and up and down the social ladder, thinking through intersections of race, class, and gender. Analyzes the role of popular culture, social media, language and dialects, capitalism, religion, and other social factors in shaping shared national experiences and local versions of American life. Probes how people in the United States experience enduring themes of aspiration, democracy, patriotism, and the dream amid pervasive economic precarity and societal dysfunction. subject: Anthropology
description: POLITICAL ANTHROPOLOGY  Discussion  The study of politics and government in the contemporary world through an anthropological emphasis on culture and cultural diversity. Examines nation-states, bureaucracy, social movements, Indigenous communities, multinational corporations, and other political forms around the world. Students have the opportunity to understand how global political systems are rooted in colonialism and capitalism, and also how political life, social experience, and everyday struggles are richly particular from place to place. subject: Anthropology
description: ENVIRONMENTAL ANTHROPOLOGY  Lecture  Examines how environments are shaped over time and how people influence or contest environmental processes. Emphasizes an anthropological focus on culture and cultural diversity, as well as politics and power. Conceptualizes environments as constructs variously defined as resource, property, nature, or territory. Considers the shaping of people’s experiences and identities in terms of their ideas about and relationships with environments. Case studies are drawn from around the world. subject: Anthropology
description: FOOD AND CULTURE  Lecture  Examines the cultural dimensions of food and eating. Topics include what foods mean in different cultures, food taboos and religious beliefs, the influence of globalization and Western consumerism, ethnocentric assumptions about health and body in diet and nutrition science, hunger and the global food crisis, and international food policy. Analyzes how businesses and social movements invoke alternatives to industrial food in terms of culture and place, such as local food, slow food, fair trade, and community supported agriculture. Broadly adopts an anthropological view of food and diet as sites of profound and dangerous transformations in human history and planetary landscapes and climate over the span of millennia. subject: Anthropology
description: SPORTS AND SOCIETY  Lecture  Examines sports across diverse cultures and societies. Topics include the spread of sports through empire and globalization, gender and sports, the global popularity of major international sports, the racialization of athletes, and media spectacles such as the Olympics and Super Bowl. Emphasizes how sports can reflect, reproduce, and challenge issues of inequality, discrimination, and identity in society. Case studies look at both popular and less popular sports around the world. subject: Anthropology
description: ECON ANTH: GIFTS, GOODS, GLOBA  Lecture  Introduces the field of economic anthropology, the study of economic issues and systems around the world. Covers classic concepts such as gifts, commodities, money, capital, and class, while exploring diverse settings of work and livelihood, industry and business, consumerism and inequality. Highlights the complex impacts of international structures and forces on local communities and environments. Vivid case studies of economic milieus, such as hunting-gathering societies, Amazon supply chains, drug cartels, Islamic banks, cryptocurrency, advertising agencies, protest movements, and college debt reveal the aspirations, activities, moral logics, hierarchies, and struggles in the economic lives of people the world over. subject: Anthropology
description: EVOLUTIONARY MEDICINE  Lecture  Surveys the field of evolutionary medicine, which examines human health and disease through an evolutionary lens. Uses principles of evolution to better understand, prevent, and treat disease. Case studies include reproductive health, infectious disease, cancer, and diet. subject: Anthropology
description: MEDICAL ANTHROPOLOGY  Lecture  Surveys the field of medical anthropology: the study of health and illness across diverse societies. Emphasizes complex relationships between biological, cultural, structural, and environmental factors shaping disease and wellbeing. Analyzes how Western medicine, biotechnology, and global health impact local health around the world. Considers how anthropology’s attention to lived experience and in-depth community studies contribute to health care practices and programs. Students will engage in critical ethical reasoning and apprehend health, sickness, and care in terms of human experience and human rights. Case studies look at COVID-19, HIV/AIDS, chronic diseases, mental health, environmental health, reproductive health, and disability, among other topics. Students interested in medicine, public health, nursing, and other health professions have the opportunity to learn frameworks and skills that are crucial for their future work. subject: Anthropology
description: CULTURE & GLOBAL HEALTH  Lecture  Provides an overview of the vast field of global health. Explores distributions of disease and the social determinants of health disparities in different parts of the world, as well as the uneven and often paradoxical impacts of Western health and medical interventions. Looks at the influence of international organizations such as the UN and WHO, corporate philanthropy, and a few powerful nations in driving dominant global health priorities. Emphasizes the value of in-depth local anthropology for understanding and addressing health challenges through community-level engagements in diverse world regions. Students interested in medicine, public health, nursing, and other health professions have the opportunity to learn frameworks and skills that are crucial for their future work. By understanding these connections and interactions, students develop crucial critical-thinking and employment skills for today’s world. Focuses on the evolutionary forces that shape human anatomy and physiology, and the interaction of human biology with adaptation as a cultural species. Examples of human biological variation to be discussed include body proportions, skin color, blood groups, hemoglobin variants, among others. subject: Anthropology
description: NUTRITIONAL ANTHROPOLOGY  Lecture  Examines the interaction of biology and culture as they affect food systems, customs, practices, and nutrition. Topics include why we eat what we eat (explanations for foodways), adaptation of food to people and people to food, foods as medicines, undernutrition and overnutrition, child and infant feeding, and solutions to diet-related problems. subject: Anthropology
description: SEX, MONEY, AND POWER  Lecture  This course allows students to understand the cultural construction of gender, power, and sexuality in relation to global economic processes that connect the family, household, and intimate relations to the world of work, commerce, and the global economy. It will demonstrate to students how what have long been considered “intimate” social relations have become geographically dispersed, impersonal, mediated by and implicated in broader political-economic or capitalist processes. Students can systematically compare their lives as women and men with those of others around the world using social-science perspectives and increase their understanding of the gendered aspects of the dynamics of global cultural and economic interaction. Students will be able to apply theories of intersectionality and feminism as well as perform critical analyses of socioeconomic dimensions of gendered lives in local and global contexts. description: AFRICAN DIASPORA AND THE WORLD  Lecture  Examines historical, geographical, and cultural dimensions of the African diaspora. subject: Anthropology
description: ARCH OF AG  Lecture  Explores the worldwide shift from hunting and gathering to agricultural lifeways thousands of years ago. Looks at major social, cultural, and environmental impacts and changes, including settlement, population growth, animal domestication, irrigation, deforestation, political hierarchies, and technological innovation. Examines the archaeological evidence and theories of how and why farming started and how agriculture has transformed all aspects of human life. subject: Anthropology
description: DEVELOPMENT & UNDERDEVELOPMENT  Lecture  Examines how economic development and globalization significantly shape societies and cultures around the world. Emphasizes complex relationships of influence and exploitation between so-called developed and underdeveloped countries. Centers the lives and struggles of global south communities, contrasting what development means at a theoretical level to fraught realities of how world development systems and interventions impact local populations and environments. Students engage in critical reasoning about international politics and economics and the problematic tendency of looking at the incredibly interconnected planet as a stark division of first and third worlds. subject: Anthropology
description: CULTURE & GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANG  Lecture  Explores climate change and precarity in diverse local settings, including marginalized communities at the edges of society, in remote geographical regions or ecological zones, and distanced from nodes of care, support, expertise, and power in the global archipelago of sprawl and stockpiles. Includes case studies of climate change impacting Indigenous peoples, refugees, nomadic groups, slum dwellers, and the rural poor. Shows how in-depth anthropology provides nuanced community-level understandings of local cultures and conditions of climate change and catastrophe, perspectives that are essential for effective problem solving and policy orientations in a diverse world. subject: Anthropology
description: GLOBAL ENVIRON SUSTAINABILITY  Lecture  Examines one of the world’s greatest challenges: environmental sustainability. Considers climate change, pollution, resource depletion, and environmental racism in diverse social and cultural contexts. Centers case studies of Indigenous peoples, social movements, and intentional communities whose values and practices offer alternative visions for human-environment relations and how to define sustainability and live sustainably. Engages current debates and approaches to environmental issues, such as the United Nations Climate Change accords, corporate sustainability platforms, and environmental justice movements. subject: Anthropology
course_name: Peoples and Cultures of Contemporary Africa
description: PEOPLES CULTURES: CONT AFRICA  Lecture  Introduces the diversity of experiences in continental Africa and challenges problematic cultural representations. Contrasts stereotypes of Africa with in-depth case studies of the diverse lives of people from and within Africa. Analyzes how communities are shaped by historical and ongoing global hierarchies of power, including colonialism, capitalism, resource extraction, medical inequalities, and humanitarianism, as well as intersections of race, gender, class, and geography. Introduces theoretical approaches from cultural, medical, and political and legal anthropology.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with AFRA 333  . Furnishes an in-depth case study of how ideas, beliefs, institutions, and cultures change in a country amid large-scale historical and transnational forces and phases. subject: Anthropology
description: INDIGENOUS PEOPLES OF LATIN A  Lecture  Examines contemporary social life among Indigenous peoples of Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Caribbean. Case studies illustrate the social and cultural diversity of Indigenous groups and histories of marginalization, struggle, and resistance amid modern nation-states and global processes. Emphasis on the leadership and participation of Indigenous people in social and political movements and changing relationships to migration, capitalism, global health, extractive industry, environmental justice, international law, and human rights. subject: Anthropology
course_name: Indigenous Arts and Media in the Americas
description: 3  INDIGENOUS ARTS & MEDIA: AMERI  Lecture  Introduces contemporary Indigenous arts and media in North America, Central America, South America, and the Caribbean. Examines the expressive forms and performance genres of Indigenous artists and communities to consider arts and culture as modes of social commentary and resources for life and survival. Topics include art markets, the commodification of indigeneity, the role of museums, copyrights and intellectual property, and transnational, diasporic, and south-south art worlds, among others. Emphasizes how issues of race, gender, class, colonialism, nation, landscape, and other social forms are crucially at stake in diverse Indigenous expressive styles and art scenes across the Western Hemisphere. subject: Anthropology
description: MOTHERHOOD & CONTESTED REPROD  Lecture  Examines the politics of reproduction in contemporary societies, as well as the intimate, personal, lived experiences of people contending with situations of contested reproduction. Case studies from around the world explore narratives about and contestations over motherhood and reproduction. Topics include abortion, international surrogacy, carceral pregnancy, in/fertility, family planning, contraception, parental labor, and early childhood. Emphasizes how these topics intersect in people’s lives with issues of race, gender, class, sexuality, and other social contrasts. Introduces theoretical approaches from cultural, medical, and political and legal anthropology.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with WOMS 343  . subject: Anthropology
description: ANTH OF CLOTHING AND FASHION  Lecture  Clothing as a starting point for examining gender, sexuality, race, the body, history, colonialism, and other broad themes. Explores the ritual significance of clothing and bodily adornment in traditional societies and the role of style in contemporary social movements and identity categories. Investigates the globalization of the fashion industry, from design and production to branding and marketing, to understand relationships among citizenship, consumption, labor, and power in the global economy. Encourages students to reflect on their relationship to the wider society and economy as producers and consumers of material culture through the lens of clothing. subject: Anthropology
description: DRUGS & CULTURE  Lecture  Explores the use of mind and body altering substances, both licit and illicit, in diverse cultures in the world today. Substances considered include stimulants (such as coffee, sugar, tobacco), coca and cocaine, narcotics, alcohol, marijuana, hallucinogens, and pharmacological agents. Case studies of different contexts of substance use, regulation, policing, and therapeutics span rural and urban, traditional and modern settings in Africa, North America, Latin America, Europe, and Asia. Students engage in critical thinking about the definition of a drug, social science understandings of addiction and substance abuse, the medical framing of addiction as a mental health disorder, religious perspectives on drugs and alcohol, and societal, moral, and policy questions about vice, crime, and illegality; transnational drug wars and human rights; mass incarceration and policing; and drug treatment and rehabilitation approaches, among other topics. This course is especially relevant for students interested in criminal justice, law, government, medicine, and other health professions. subject: Anthropology
course_name: Powerful Bodies: Gender, Normativity, and Diversity in Sports
description: POWERFUL BODIES  Lecture  Takes sports as a lens onto social issues of gender, health, hierarchy, body, violence, and normativity in a diverse range of societies around the world. Case studies of athlete experiences, sports cultures, and sports capitalism look at: injury and physical and sexual abuse in sports; the role of medicine and pharmaceuticals in norming fitness, endurance, and vulnerability standards; the cultural, political, and economic influence of corporations and the media on athletics; the erotics of athletic physicality, intimacy, and performance; considerations and issues regarding disabled and trans athletes; the social world of sports video games, fantasy sports, and sports gambling; and doping scandals, among other topics. Covers numerous sports across world regions, from basketball and soccer to sumo wrestling, combat sports, animal sports, ordinary activities like running and exercise, and mass spectacles such as the Olympics, looking at examples in the United States as well as Asia, Europe, Latin America, and Africa. Adopts intersectional approaches to emphasize how race, gender, and other social forms shape the ways power, discrimination, inequality, and visibility play out on the field and outside the lines.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with WOMS 347  . subject: Anthropology
description: TOPICS IN ANTHROPOLOGY  Lecture  Examines contemporary challenges and debates from anthropological perspectives and applying anthropological ways of thinking. Focus on current world problems: topics include migration and refugees; environmental sustainability and food security; climate change; war, imperialism, and ethnic violence; religious strife; nationalism, transnationalism, and postnationalism; economic and social inequity; race and racism; and gender identities and relations. Students will explore these problems and debates using diverse methods.  Y 3 N Student Option  Discovery Learning Experience  Sustainability Connections

Topics include colonialism, gender, geopolitics, globalization, and environmental and social justice. Regions covered are the Caribbean, Mexico and Central America, and the Andean, Atlantic, and Southern Cone regions of South America.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with AFRA 351  . subject: Anthropology
description: REFUGEES AND FORCED MIGRATION  Lecture  Examines social, cultural, political, and economic dimensions of refugee crises and forced migration. Topics include the definition of a refugee and what situations are covered by that definition, humanitarianism and global responses to refugees, the securitization of border regimes, the management of refugees in camps and urban areas, climate change induced displacement, and new directions in migration policy worldwide. Case studies are global, with attention to forced migration to and from North America, South America, continental Africa, Europe, and the Pacific. Introduces theoretical approaches from cultural, medical, and political and legal anthropology. subject: Anthropology
description: GLOBAL HUMANITARIANISM  Discussion  Examines the representation, production, ethics, and politics of humanitarianism across various global case studies. Considers a central contradiction of humanitarianism, which claims to treat human life as universal while ignoring how specific populations and interventions are stratified by race, sexuality, gender, nationality, and place. Compares public framings and the celebrity spectacle of humanitarianism with lived experiences of people who receive aid. Introduces theoretical approaches from cultural, medical, and political and legal anthropology.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with POSC 354  or WOMS 354  . subject: Anthropology
description: CULTURE, LAW, HUMAN RIGHTS  Lecture  Examines cultural dimensions of law and human rights. Approaches law not just as a set of procedures, but also a system of cultural meanings and moral values. Considers the changing relationship of law to state power, the global economy, and social movements. Combines readings from legal anthropology with journalism and human rights reports from around the world. Especially suited for students concerned with law, policy, government, social justice, and cultural diversity. subject: Anthropology
description: ANTHROPOLOGY OF CHILDHOOD  Lecture  Many aspects of childhood that seem inevitable or natural are, in fact, shaped by culture and not rooted in biology. Examines childhood from biological and cultural perspectives, including how humans compare to nonhuman primates and how humans vary today and through time. Topics include growth and development, cultural definitions of childhood, parenting, among others.  N 3 N Student Option  Social and Behavioral Sciences GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci Multicultural Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally   GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications GE5A: Reason Quantitatively  GE5C: Reason Scientifically

subject: Anthropology
description: CLIMATE REFUGEES  Lecture  “Unprecedented” situations of environmental degradation and disaster are becoming increasingly regular as a result of climate change, which in turn makes many places uninhabitable and displaces thousands of people. Yet, there are few international, regional, and local responses to environmental displacement which recognize the right for and legitimacy of people moving as a result of these processes. This course examines these situations of environmental displacement by engaging with research emerging out of the disciplines of anthropology, geography, and other related social and environmental sciences, as well as through examining relevant international, national, and regional policies.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with POSC 357  and GEOG 357  .  Social and Behavioral Sciences GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci Multicultural  Sustainability Investigations Spring

subject: Anthropology
course_name: American Anabaptists: Amish, Mennonite and Brethren Cultures
description: AMERICAN ANABAPTISTS  Lecture  Examines the history and culture of Amish, Mennonite, and Brethren communities in the United States, including in the region around Delaware. Emphasizes how these groups have established and maintained a visible and distinctive identity separate from mainstream American culture, and explores the merchandising and consumption of their separate identity through tourism. subject: Anthropology
description: WOMEN IN CROSS-CULTURAL PERSPE  Lecture  Social realities and roles of women across diverse cultures. How institutions such as motherhood, the family, sexuality, and work structure women’s lives within dominant social and cultural ideologies.  Y 6 N Student Option  Crosslisted with WOMS 363  . Students may earn from one to six academic credits. description: SEMINAR  Lecture  Y 99 Y Student Option

subject: Anthropology
description: GLOBAL FOOD PROBLEMS  Lecture  Examines the global food crisis. Compares food production, consumption, and distribution patterns around the world, and the unequal health and wealth outcomes of these systems. Considers historical roots and structural causes of food insecurity, malnutrition, and food loss and waste. Assesses the role of industrial agriculture, climate change, and economic inequalities on hunger and other food problems, as well as the policies and international political responses seeking to address them. subject: Anthropology
description: COLONIALISM AND CULTURE  Lecture  Examines the history and culture of European colonialism in Africa, Asia, and the Americas, looking at the development of social norms, modes of fashion and style, logics of race and gender, and governance and social control. Analyzes how the contemporary world has emerged out of colonialism and complicated extensions of colonial cultural forms into the present. Students have the opportunity to understand how inequalities, conflicts, duress, and dysfunction the world over have been made durable as a result of prolonged relations of empire. subject: Anthropology
course_name: Peoples and Cultures of Contemporary Latin America
description: PEOPLES & CULTRS:CONT LAT AMER  Lecture  Examines contemporary cultures and societies of Latin America, looking at how history, politics, economy, and globalization shape people’s lives. Case studies of different parts of Latin America delve into such topics as citizenship, the elite, cities and countrysides, pop culture, the military, religion, social justice, and environmental issues. Emphasizes contexts and intersections of race, gender, class, ethnicity, and other social contrasts. Covers the Caribbean, Mexico and Central America, and the Andean, Atlantic, and Southern Cone regions of South America. This 4-credit course with a service learning component fulfills the Discovery Learning Experience requirement.  N 4 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with AFRA 375  . subject: Anthropology
course_name: Archaeology and Colonialism in North America
description: ARCHAEOLOGY & COLONIALISM  Lecture  Examines the history of colonial North America through a focus on archaeological sites and materials. Emphasizes issues of power and oppression that have pervaded imperialism, capitalism, and settler colonialism around the world. Considers particularities of indigeneity, nationalism, racism, and resistance in North American colonial societies and experience. Affords students an opportunity to engage de-colonizing ways of teaching and researching colonized populations.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with HIST 379  . subject: Anthropology
description: CULTU REP OF NATIVE AMERICANS  Lecture  Examines the representation of Native Americans in popular culture and the arts in the United States, including film, photography, advertising, literature, media, and sports. Analyzes how popular representations reflect stereotypes about Native Americans and how they function as forms of power and racial discrimination in contemporary society.  N 3 N Student Option  Creative Arts and Humanities GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities Multicultural Fall   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation  GE2B: Communicate Orally   GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications   GE5C: Reason Scientifically

subject: Anthropology
description: CAPITALISM AND CULTURE  Lecture  Examines the cultures and impacts of capitalism around the world. Themes include the globalization of capitalism, cultures of labor and work, meanings of class and taste, artistic responses to capitalism, major anti-capitalism social movements, the meanings of economic development, the entanglement of capitalism with warfare, and the vibrancy of music, film, and fashion as areas where core values of capitalism are both advanced and contested. Students have the opportunity to develop critical understanding and skills for engaging the consumerism, relationships, and lived experiences of advanced capitalism.  N 3 N Student Option  Social and Behavioral Sciences GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci  Sustainability Connections Fall   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing   GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Anthropology
course_name: Globalization on the Ground: Cultural Diversity and Contemporary Life
description: GLOBALIZATION ON THE GROUND  Lecture  Overviews how global flows of ideas, people, and things impact life experiences around the world. Explores how globalization makes life both homogenous and fragmented. In-depth case studies analyze the consumption of global foods, entertainment, social media, and other things, as well as experiences of race, class, gender, sexuality, and other social contrasts in particular places. Broadly considers how local understandings of diversity, identity, and community are crucial for adequate theories of modernity and the global.  N 3 N Student Option  History and Cultural Change GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change Multicultural Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally  GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Anthropology
description: CINEMA AND GLOBAL CULTURES  Lecture  Movies are more than “entertainment.” They tell us meaningful things about ourselves and the world. They are a lens onto identities and fundamental social issues in a multicultural world. Drawing on popular movies, blockbusters, arthouse films, and documentaries, the course looks at a diverse array of contemporary cinematic representations of social life and social struggles from around the world. This course screens numerous films and film clips, including from Eastern Europe, Africa, Latin America, India, and East Asia, among other places. Topics include forces of globalization; race, gender, and sexuality; immigration and senses of place; issues of war, terrorism, and representation; climate change and the environment; and the power of digital film for social change.  N 3 N Student Option  Creative Arts and Humanities GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities Multicultural Fall and Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing   GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Anthropology
description: CONTEMP AMERICAN CINEMA  Lecture  Surveys film in the United States from the nineties to the present. Examines cinematic  depictions of what America means at the moment: the diverse aspirations and anxieties,  fantasies and realities, dreams and nightmares of different segments of society. Analyzes  how contemporary films thematize such topics as family, love, success, citizenship, protest, and inequality, storying the dramas and comedies of identity, community, conflict, struggle, and wellbeing in a discordant and multicultural country. Explores cinema’s function as both social commentary and entertainment industry, how movies can reflect and challenge norms and narratives of nation, populace, freedom, and land. Genres include romcom, horror, coming-of-age, crime, neo-western, animation, road movies, buddy movies, and movies about the Iraq War, among others. For this 4-credit class, 3 credits are for standard in-class contact and 1 credit accounts for assigned films to be watched each week by students on their own.  N 4 N Student Option  History and Cultural Change GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change Multicultural Verify offering with Dept   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally  GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Anthropology
description: CONTEMP QUEER CINEMA  Lecture  Examines queer cinema from the nineties to the present, looking at various types of movies from around the world. Explores how contemporary cinema represents queer identities and experiences in diverse societies and at intersections of race, gender, class, and other social contrasts. Incorporates films and film clips from various cinema traditions (East Asia, Europe, Latin America, Bollywood, United States) and genres (romcom, melodrama, horror, sci-fi, coming-of-age, animation, documentary) to consider how cinema contributes to queer readings and understandings of such issues as pleasure and precarity, freedom and violence, health and the body, family and citizenship, beauty and banality. Analyzes queer cinema, ultimately, as a global arts practice and a powerful and nuanced mode of social commentary and representational politics. For this 4-credit class, 3 credits are for standard in-class contact and 1 credit accounts for assigned films to be watched each week by students on their own.  N 4 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with WOMS 386  . description: AFRICANA-EDUCATION CAPSTONE  Field Studies  This course works in conjunction with the student teaching of AFRA Social Studies Education Concentration students. This course prepares student-teachers to teach from an Africana Studies focus, one which includes contributions and perspectives of people of African origin. subject: Africana Studies
description: RELIGION & SOCIAL JUSTICE  Lecture  Many scholars and communities believe that experience affects the ways in which people conceive of and practice their faith.  This course explores faith and freedom from various social and cultural perspectives, examining how different groups conceive of God, faith and their own actions in struggles against oppression. Develops conversational ability without using voice/hearing any sounds and culturally appropriate behaviors such as ASL immersion. subject: Animal and Food Sciences
description: ANIMALS AND HUMAN CULTURE  Lecture  Animals have important roles in human society and their significance varies across diverse cultural settings. Explore human-animal interactions on issues related to food and fiber production, welfare, conservation, research, work and service, natural and man-made disasters, zoonotic disease, and human health. subject: Animal and Food Sciences
description: ANIMALS, SCIENCE AND SOCIETY  Lecture  An introduction to the understanding of how domestic food animals function - genetics, nutrition, reproductive physiology, behavior and animal health. The course begins with a dialogue about the human-animal bond and the role of animals in society, and ends with the discussion of how agricultural animals are managed to produce safe and healthy food. description: FROM THE COW TO THE CONE  Lecture  Explores the science and technology of flavorings, freezing,production and quality control of ice cream and other frozen desserts. Students learn what it takes to create, market and manage a competitive ice cream business from start to finish; study the latest ice cream trends; and develop products in the UDairy Creamery. subject: Animal and Food Sciences
description: FARM TO TABLE  Lecture  How does food get from the farm to your table? Explore traditional agriculture and contemporary food production models like Community Supported Agriculture (CSA), community gardens and the local food movement. Learn about new crops and dietary strategies that can be incorporated into the way people eat today. Examine cultural influences on food production and consumption patterns, and biocultural aspects of nutrition. Students will complete several projects that include interviews, research, food shopping excursions, film critiques and menu planning. Students will volunteer at the Delaware Food Bank and/or Gardens for the Community.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with PLSC 206  , ANTH 206  , and HBNS 206  .   Sustainability Investigations

subject: Animal and Food Sciences
description: CLIN PRE-VET EXP 1  Lecture  General overview of practical skills needed within the field of Clinical Small Animal Veterinary Medicine.  Students complete the course with a better understanding of some expected skills of a veterinary assistant and how to perform them.  Students successfully completing this course have the opportunity to complete an externship over Winter session in a small animal veterinary hospital to continue their training. subject: Animal and Food Sciences
description: CLIN PRE-VET EXP 2  Lecture  The course follows Clinical Pre-veterinary Experience 1 and reinforces practical skills needed within the field of Clinical Small Animal Veterinary Medicine.  Students  complete the course with a more in-depth understanding of expected skills of any veterinary assistant or technician and how to perform them. subject: Anthropology
description: INTRO TO CULTURAL ANTHROPOLO  Lecture  Introduces the concepts, theories, and methods of cultural anthropology, a field of study that examines the diversity of human societies and the dynamics of culture. Students learn to think cross-culturally about contemporary social problems and how to address them. Covers topics such as gender, family, ritual, politics, identity, health, and the environment, and offers knowledge and approaches that are directly applicable in daily life and a wide variety of careers. subject: Anthropology
description: HUMAN BIOLOGY BEHAVIOR EVOLU  Lecture  Introduces the science of biological anthropology: the study of humanity and human origins from a biological perspective, the relationship of modern humans to nonhuman primates, the complex interaction of biology and culture in the evolutionary development of the human species, and modern human variation and adaptation across environments and contexts. Explores how anthropologists use the fossil record and material culture to learn about the past and understand the present. Explores how archaeology contributes to the broad knowledge of human diversity and cultures. Case studies are drawn from around the world, including ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia, the Maya, the Indus Valley, and ancient China. Emphasis on how anthropologists study and develop scientific understandings of the past. Covers a basic understanding of genetics, biological evolution, the origins and diversity of primates, and the origins and diversity of human cultures. description: DIGITAL HERITAGE  Bridge course for transitioning ELI students as well as an introductory course for “domestic students” to cultural heritage and specifically digital heritage. course_name: Studio in the Materials and Techniques of Drawing in the West
description: STUDIO/MAT&TECH DRAWING/WEST  Lecture  Lecture-studio presentation on materials and tools, supports and techniques of wet and dry media drawing in the West from about the year 1400 to the present. Topics include the development and manufacture of paper, pens, brushes, inks, watercolor paint, charcoal, metal points, graphite pencils, natural and fabricated chalks, crayons, pastels, erasers and fixatives. Studio reconstructions of masterworks, lectures and library research.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with ARTH 280  . Requires permission of instructor.  Verify offering with Dept

subject: Art Conservation
course_name: Studio in the Materials and Techniques of Textiles I
description: STUDIO MTRLS&TECHS TEXTILES I  Lecture  Studio course on terminology and techniques of textile making. Students will complete a variety of small projects from knitting and felting, weaving and embroidery. Explore a variety of tools and manufacturing methods from around the world and learn basic stitches that can be used in craft as well as conservation practice. Class will include brief lectures and student-led research as well as plenty of time for making. subject: Asian Studies
course_name: Confucius, Emperor, and Lama: Eurasian China since 1300
description: CONFUCIUS, EMPEROR, AND LAMA  Lecture  This course examines how China developed into a Eurasian state from the Yuan Dynasty of the Mongol Empire in the fourteenth century to the People’s Republic of China in the twentieth century. It discusses the ongoing consequences of this transformation for East Asia, Inner Asia, Southeast Asia, and the world. Major topics include the rise and fall of Mongol and Manchu regimes in China, China’s conquests of Xinjiang and Tibet, the reconstruction of the Great Wall, racial and ethnic relations within the Chinese empire, Ming China’s maritime voyages, Sinocentric world order and international trade, Jesuit missionaries in China, rituals and religions, domestic and cross-border migrations, border negotiations, international law, Chinese and Western colonialism and imperialism, and modern Chinese nationalism.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with HIST 364  .  History and Cultural Change GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change Multicultural Fall   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally GE2C: Communicate Through Creative Expression GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications GE5A: Reason Quantitatively

subject: Africana Studies
description: THE PROBLEM OF THE COLOR-LINE  Lecture  Immerse yourself in a comprehensive exploration of the concept of race in this thought-provoking and empirically driven course. Delve into its complexities of race as a dynamic interplay of contradictory forces, facts, and tendencies. Examine race’s role as a classificatory system of power and meaning, and its profound influence on socio-historical policies and practices. Analyze how race functions in various domains and how it influences human behavior, critically assessing the empirical evidence that highlights the discriminatory effects race has in various quality-of-life contexts. Finally, question the accuracy of Dr. W.E.B. Du Bois’ prediction about the problem of the 20th century being the problem the color line and delve into the enduring consequences of race as a pervasive worldview.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with SOCI 217  .  Social and Behavioral Sciences GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci Fall and Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information GE1C: Engage in Constructive Ideation GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally  GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications GE5A: Reason Quantitatively

subject: Africana Studies
course_name: Race and Sports in American Society
description: RACE AND SPORTS  Examines the salient issues in U.S. society such as racism, capitalism, sexism, violence, oppression, etc. by using the context of sport to explore the social and cultural experiences of African Americans from slavery to today. It allows students to see both the cultural agency of African Americans and the pervasiveness of racial oppression that exist in and out of sports world. Analyze the experience of race in U.S. sports in relationship to its historical, cultural, social, economic, and political dynamics. Identify, analyze, discuss and critique theories regarding race and ethnic relations in U.S. sports. Develop critical thinking and analytical skills by comparing and contrasting the experiences of African Americans with other groups.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with SOCI 221  .  Multicultural Fall and Spring

subject: Africana Studies
description: RACIAL POLITICS IN SPORTS  Investigates the politics of race in the U. S. sports with particular attention to the political status of African Americans, and white prejudice and discrimination. Ask such questions as: Is there racism in sports? How can we tell if ads are racist, and whether sports team owners are using code words to appeal to racial prejudices? Is kneeling for the anthem to protest the treatment of Black Americans unpatriotic? Are race-conscious policies really necessary? Should Black athletes use sports to protest socio-political issues? Seek to answer these questions and more by studying the systemic forms of oppression and discussing various cultural perspectives in an atmosphere of intellectual rigor and mutual respect for opposing views. Develop your understanding race by using the context of sport to explore many salient issues in American society such as racism, blind patriotism, capitalism, sexism, violence, oppression, etc. Enhance your critical thinking skills, information literacy skills, and your ability to place historical and contemporary issues in proper context.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with POSC 222  .  History and Cultural Change (HIST & CLT) Multicultural Winter and Summer

subject: Africana Studies
description: SPORTS, MEDIA & CULTURE  Lecture  This course examines the interrelationship of sports, media, and culture in today’s society and how that interrelationship sometimes reinforces or challenge social values. It draws on the cultural identification of class, race, and gender to identify sports values and cultural values. Drawing on theories of culture, rhetoric, and social criticism, we will examine media’s role in telling the story of sports and, in telling that story, shapes cultural values. Students will study several critical approaches to sports and public discourse and will apply those approaches to journalism, public relations, the news and popular media, and other forms of mass communication.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with COMM 223  .  Social and Behavioral Sciences GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci Multicultural Fall, Winter, Spring, Summer   GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information  GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally  GE3A: Work Collaboratively Across Cultures  GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Africana Studies
course_name: Race and Racism: Global History and Representation
description: RACE AND RACISM  Lecture  Racism is a hot-button issue globally. Although thoroughly debunked and are more widely condemned than ever, it nevertheless continues to surface in government policies, popular representations, and brutal acts of violence. What is it that makes racism so intractable? This course works to answer that question by analyzing racism as a problem that’s deeply em-bedded in Western societies, albeit similarly prevalent in many non-Western countries. We’ll also look at how racism connects with other social categories such as Indigeneity, gender, sexuality, disability, religion and class. And in addition to considering how racism has oper-ated to oppress, exclude and scapegoat, we’ll also be attentive to how marginalized groups have fought back.  N 3 N Student Option  Crosslisted with HIST 224  , ANTH 224  , ARTH 260  , ENGL 224  , GEOG 224  , and WOMS 244  .  History and Cultural Change GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change Multicultural Fall and Spring   GE1A: Read Critically GE1B: Analyze Arguments and Information  GE2A: Communicate Effectively in Writing GE2B: Communicate Orally   GE3B: Work Independently Across Cultures GE4: Critically Evaluate Ethical Implications

subject: Africana Studies
description: BLACK MALE EXPERIENCE  Explores the complex and diverse experiences of African American males in contemporary U.S. society by examining the various factors impacting their lives such as family, education, prison, sports, relationships, etc. This allows a better understanding of the thoughts and practices of African American males as well as the impact they have on society as a whole. Include an intersectional lens of analysis that includes race, gender, sexuality, age, disability, and socio-economic class.  N 3 N Student Option  May be crosslisted with WOMS 225  .  Social and Behavioral Sciences GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci Multicultural Fall and Spring
